title: The Indexing Initiative
story: Accessing specific elements in arrays is fundamental to ML! Whether selecting features, filtering data, or creating subsets, mastering NumPy indexing lets you manipulate data with precision. Boolean indexing is especially powerful for filtering!
instructions: Import numpy as np. Create array `values` with [5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30]. Get `first_three` (first 3 elements), `last_two` (last 2 elements), and `greater_than_15` (elements > 15 using boolean indexing). Print all three.
solutionHidden:
import numpy as np
values = np.array([5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30])
first_three = values[:3]
last_two = values[-2:]
greater_than_15 = values[values > 15]
print(first_three)
print(last_two)
print(greater_than_15)

tests.expectedBehavior: Output should show sliced and filtered arrays

hints.text: Use slicing [:3] for first 3, [-2:] for last 2. Boolean indexing: array[array > value]
Boolean indexing creates a mask: values > 15 returns [False, False, False, True, True, True]
first_three = values[:3], last_two = values[-2:], greater_than_15 = values[values > 15]
